attachments.text: James Goldstein’s singular style is reflected best in his architectural marvel of a house-turned-club.

attachments.title: Are Branding Agencies Still Relevant?
attachments.text: The old way of designing brands is in desperate need of a rethink, writes Edenspiekermann’s Paul Woods.
attachments.fallback: Co.Design: Are Branding Agencies Still Relevant?

text: hmmm - I feel like the author is angry at someone specific and is working it out in this article
like “Increasingly a brand is defined by what a product actually delivers”
this has always been true, this isn’t a new concept
and also - is it just me, or does he switch back and forth between using “branding” to mean “identity system” and “branding” to mean “branding”?

agreed that this has always been a thing, but i think it’s becoming increasingly a thing. Having worked at a “traditional” branding studio that thinks of “digital” as completely secondary, I feel what he’s trying to say.
I *think* get what he’s trying to say, but I also feel like I’m meeting him more than half way there
I still content he’s conflating “brand” and “identity”

like here “Spotify gives me easy access to a world of music. Do I care what it looks like? Probably not, once it has a great user experience. In fact, it would probably work equally as well as a white label app. For the user, the brand is defined by what it does, not by its logo or color palette.”
any way - at this point I’m just complaining

whether or not he’s conflating them intentionally, i can’t really tell. I think he’s arguing that studios that call them selves branding studios are only addressing a small piece of the puzzle and that piece is becoming increasingly less relevant, which i agree with. At the very least, starting with a logo / identity seems misguided.
